comments:
Environment:
Java: Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build 1.4.2_04-b05)
Eclipse:  SDK v3.2
CDT: 3.1

After creating a new "standard" project and pointing to the root directory of the source code (there are thousands of .c* files), CDT begings to report that it is performing a "Refresh Workspace".  This seems to run for hours and eventually it crashes telling me that it has run out of memory.  Note that I have the indexer turned off as this caused crashes of its own but I can live without the indexer.

I looked at the help for this problem and it recommended increasing the amount of memory Eclipse is allowed to access.  So, I ran Eclipse in the following manner:
./eclipse -vmargs -Xmx512M -XX:MaxPermSize=256M

However, CDT/Eclipse still crashed.

Here is the .log file from the workspace:

How many thousands of files? How much physical memory do you have?

I have never used the -XX:MaxPermSize=256M option. Could you try without it?

We test regulary with the Mozilla source that has around 30,000 files in it with no problems. Refreshing resources does take a few minutes, though.
This may happen due to cyclic symbolic links. See also bug 105554.

Interesting...  I have about the same number of files in my project.  I tried creating a project that is a subspace of my full project (ie. one directory fromt he project root) and everything seems to run fine.

I tried to run elclipse without the -XX:MaxPermSize=256M option and had similar results as with the option on.  Here is the .log file from that run:

I had a look at bug 105554.  I don't believe I have cyclic symbolic links in my project.  The source is organized as follows (The directories typically go deeper but I think this gives the general idea):


dir1/subdir1/foo.c -> ../source/foo1.c
dir1/subdir2/foo.c -> ../source/foo1.c
dir1/subdir3/foo.c -> ../source/foo2.c
dir2/subdir1/goo.c -> ../source/goo1.c
...
etc.

Where the source directory holds all the actual source code and all other files are symbolic links.  Could this be the cause of the problem?

subdir1 and source share the same parent directory which may not be clear from what I showed.  The reason I displayed it this way is to make sure it is clear the the symbolic links are relative to the subdirectory they're in in case this is the cause of the problem.  In other words, if you do and "ls -l" in subdir1, you will see

foo.c -> ../source/foo1.c
